Author: Devdas Bhagat
Comment:
SQL JOINs are just a way of combining two sets.

I suggest starting off with understanding the natural join, and then follow up with the rest.

I also recommend reading up on CJ Date, and EF Codd’s works.

Author: Phil
Comment: Yeah, I understand perfectly how they work and what they do, I just don’t have a built-in parser like I do for most other things. Consider it a sort of blind spot 🙂

Author: Owen
Comment: You obviously need to do more hardcore logic programming 🙂 . If you get to the point where you read your own prolog after a week, plain old boring propositional SQL seems like a breeze.

Author: Phil
Comment: Wow, it has been a long, long time since I’ve had to write any prolog! I’m glad to say that I can only summon vaguely positive memories.

Author: Luke Maciak
Comment: I was like that too. And then I ended up working on a database-centric application which required me to write so many SQL JOIN statements that at one point the built in mental parser just clicked in. 🙂

Author: Phil
Comment: I think ORM tools may have corrupted me forever 🙂

Author: Ciaran
Comment:
I have to admit I still find it easier to parse the old-fashioned (some might say Oracle-style) of joins, rather than the explicit syntax.

e.g. SELECT \* FROM table1 a,table2 b WHERE a.field=b.field

But I appreciate that writing that kind of thing is, these days, on a par with farting at the in-laws dinner table.
